R. China; School of Chemical Sciences University of Chinese Academy of Sciences Beijing 100049 P. R. China With high theoretical energy density and the natural abundance of S, lithium-sulfur (Li–S) batteries are considered to be the promising next generation high-energy rechargeable energy storage devices. However, issues including electronical insulation of S, the lithium polysulfides (LiPSs) dissolution and the short cycle lifespan have prevented Li–S batteries from being practical applied. Feasible settlements of confining LiPSs to reduce the loss of active substances and improve the cycle stability include wrapping sulfur with compact layers, designing matrix with porous or hollow structures, adding adsorbents owning strong interaction with sulfur and inserting polysulfide barriers between cathodes and separators. This review categorizes them into physical and chemical confinements according to the influencing mechanism. With further discussion of their merits and flaws, synergy of the physical and chemical confinement is believed to be the feasible avenue that can guide Li–S batteries to the practical application. Graphical abstract Physical (coating, loading and separating) and chemical methods (bonding interactions) to encapsulate sulfur and suppress shuttle effect are introduced and compared. Methods combining physical and chemical confinement are considered as preferred strategies in Li-S batteries. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Lithium-sulfur batteries Confinement of polysulfides Physical structure design Chemical bonding Shuttle effect 1 Introduction With the rapid development and progress of the society, energy consumption has become an increasingly severe issue [1–3]. However, the conventional energy sources such as coal and oil, are gradually depleting and conflicts with the global environmental protection. The ever increasing demand green energy, such as wind, solar and hydro power, promoted the rapid development of energy storage devices [4,5]. Batteries can store and release energy well through electrochemical reactions and have been successfully used as a bridge for high-efficient energy utilization. Since 1990s, lithium-ion batteries with high energy density, low self-discharge rate, long cycle life and other advantages have played a vital role in the widespread application of portable electronic devices and the promising alternative of large-scale energy storage technology [6,7]. However, lithium-ion batteries based on conventional intercalation electrode materials have approached to their theoretical energy density, which limits the further application. Therefore, development of novel energy-storage systems with high energy densities remains a stringent requirement [8,9]. One alternative system, lithium-sulfur (Li–S) battery, has attracted intense interests for many years, due to its high theoretical energy density of 2600 Wh kg−1, which is an order of magnitude higher than that of conventional batteries (Fig. 1 a) [10,11]. With appropriate optimization, the battery enabling practical energy density of about 400 Wh kg−1 could support more than 400 km for electric vehicles [12,13]. In addition, the abundance and non-toxicity of sulfur provide the batteries with improved energy economy and environmental friendliness [12,14,15]. These qualities make Li–S batteries one of the promising candidates for the next-generation energy storage devices [16]. The electrochemical process of Li–S batteries differs from that of conventional lithium-ion batteries based on intercalation electrodes which is known as the rocking-chair progress. Upon discharging, cyclical molecules of elemental sulfur S8 accept electrons and generate Li2S8, corresponding to the plateau at 2.35 V; from 2.35 V to 2.05 V, long chain lithium polysulfides (Li2S x , 4 ≤ x ≤ 6) are reduced from Li2S8. The following plateau from the region of 2.05 V associated with the further reaction to Li2S2 and Li2S [2,12]. Long chain lithium polysulfides (LiPSs) are able to dissolve into the organic solvent of electrolyte and transfer through the separators to the anode while the insoluble products, Li2S2 and Li2S deposit on the anode side (Fig. 1b). Accompanied with several disproportionation reactions between different valence states of polysulfide, the electrode process of Li–S batteries is in a complex state [17–20]. The complicated electrochemistry of sulfur and its soluble polysulfides species bring inevitable challenges into the process of practical application of Li–S batteries. The main obstacle might be the irreversible capacity fading of Li–S batteries caused by dissolved intermediates and insoluble reduced products. Long chain lithium polysulfides (Li2S8, Li2S6 and Li2S4) forming upon discharging are soluble in the ether electrolyte. Driven by chemical potential and concentration difference between the cathode and the anode, long chain lithium polysulfides will diffuse to the lithium anode and subsequently be reduced to short chain polysulfides (Li2S and Li2S2), which is called shuttle effect [21]. Insulating Li2S could coat on the anode, which reduces the amount of active sulfur species and polarizes Li anode as well as lowers Coulombic efficiency [22,23]. To restrain the shuttle effect, much effort has been devoted to providing stable confinement of LiPSs. In this review, strategies of suppressing or reducing the shuttle effect are classified into physical confinement and chemical bonding which concentrates on designing special structures and introducing strong interaction sites respectively. According to the models that confine LiPSs, physical confinement is summarized as coating, loading and separating, while chemical confinement through various bonding is discussed as three parts, polar–polar interaction, Lewis acid-based interaction and sulfurization. It is worth to note that recently sulfur cathodes synergizing physical and chemical modification exhibit the optimal electrochemical performance. Moreover, the synergistic strategy which possesses the both merits of physical and chemical confinement is highlighted in this review. 2 Physical confinement In order to restrain the diffusion of polysulfides, researches focused on setting up barriers on the way that LiPSs transfer, such as wrapping sulfur with compact coating layers, loading sulfur in hollow materials and inserting isolation interlayers. With appropriate design in structures, polysulfides can be effectively confined into cathode side. In this section, some recent progresses about structure optimization for polysulfides confinement are comprehensively classified from three perspectives, coating, loading and separating. 2.1 Coating Surface coating is a progress of wrapping a covering layer on the active materials, which is an effective method for suppressing shuttle effect in Li–S batteries. For the cathode, an ideal covering layer is expected to be characterized with high conductivity, homogeneous surface and stable structure. With high electrical conductivity, dense structure and elastic nature, carbon is a remarkable coating material which has been successfully employed in enhancing the electrochemical performances of various electrode materials [24–26]. Considering that the specific energy and cycling life are equally important for practical application of Li–S batteries, coating layers which are of no electrochemical activity are expected to occupy the minimum weight in the composited cathodes and thus diminish the loss of practical specific energy of the up-coming commercial Li–S batteries [27–29]. Among the various carbonaceous coating materials, graphene has taken the most interests [8,29,30] because of its superiorities of light, large surface area, flexibility and high mechanical strength [31]. In addition, the naturally stacked structure of graphene can effectively prevent the polysulfides from transferring to anodes. Cao et al. [32] fabricated flexible freestanding reduced graphene oxide films and combined it with sulfur nanoparticles. The nanostructured architecture plays the role of pathways for electron transport and contributes to suppress the diffusion of polysulfides during the cycling process. The work demonstrated that graphene could perform well as the coating layer in the cathode. Later, Wang's group [33] presented a cathode with ultrahigh sulfur content fabricated by using the reverse microemulsion technique. Via mixing two cyclohexane microemulsions that contained carboxylated graphene–sodium polysulfide and hydrochloric acid, respectively, the graphene-wrapped sulfur composite with 94% sulfur ratio was generated. The composite demonstrated excellent cycling stability that the cathode retained the capacity of 1256 mA h g−1 after 200 cycles with more than 99% capacity retention as shown in Fig. 2 . Compared to the conventional methods such as mechanical milling and chemical precipitation, reverse microemulsion synthesis is able to make the graphene exfoliate completely and contact to the sulfur firmly. And composited cathodes fabricated by the strategy can make Li–S batteries exhibit superior performance. Another reason of graphene taking the main role in carbon coating materials is that traditional carbon coating techniques usually require thermal treatment at an elevated temperature which is beyond the boiling point of sulfur [12]. Thus, researches were concentrated on low-temperature coating technique with graphene [34,35] or active materials with high boiling point (Li2S) [36–38]. Li et al. [39] developed an effective way of coating alucone film onto the carbon-sulfur matrix by molecular layer deposition (MLD) at room temperature, shown in Fig. 3 (a). With employing trimethylaluminum and ethylene glycol, a thin metal-organic film composed of Al2O3 unit linked by –O–C2H4–O– units was coated on C–S electrodes. The alucone coating layer enabled the use of carbonate-based electrolyte in Li–S batteries and exhibit a safe and ultrastable cycle life (300 cycles in LiPF6–carbonate) at 55 °C. They proposed that the improvement on cycling stability was attributed to few SO4 2− which formed from the reaction of alucone coating and sulfur, ended up passivating the electrode surface and side reactions. The technique is significant for sulfur cathodes, which enables the use of electrolyte extending to carbonate solvents in Li–S batteries. Discovery of conductive polymers provides a novel alternative material for Li–S batteries. Various polymers have been used in cathodes of Li–S batteries, such as polypyrrole (PPy) [40], polythiophene (PTh) [41], polyvinyl carbazole (PVK) [42], polyaniline (PANi) [43]. Conductive polymer Poly(3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene) (PEDOT) has received much attention because its chain structure has stronger interactions with Li2S and Li2S2 compared to PPy and PANi. And cathodes with PEDOT could show a better cycling performance [44]. According to Cui's work, sulfur coated with PEDOT maintained a specific capacity of 1165 mA h g−1 after 500 cycles in 0.5 C, which established the polymer as an outstanding alternative for extending the lifetime of Li–S batteries. 2.2 Loading Sulfur loading is a process of introducing sulfur into the fabricated matrixes which have enough pore or room to accommodate sulfur. The most widely used method to fill the matrixes with sulfur is melt diffusion. Typically, the matrixes mixed with a certain amount of sulfur are sealed in a container and heated at 155 °C at which melt sulfur has the lowest viscosity and is easy to penetrate into matrixes. Due to capillary effect, sulfur infiltrates the hosts and fills up the pore. Melt-diffusion method is the most widely used strategy because of its high efficiency and close contact between sulfur and matrixes. Therefore, melt-diffusion method and porous carbon are called “the best partners” [45]. In addition, hosts with special structures or fabricated by special materials apply to some other strategies for preparing sulfur cathode composites, such as ball milling, vapor deposition and liquid phase precipitation. Ball milling is the method that grinds and mixed sulfur with the hosts, which is easy to operation. However, sulfur processed by ball-milling method is usually in cluster and has a weak contact with hosts. Therefore, the method has quite limited application in preparing high performance cathode composited. An available application of ball milling to fabricate the cathode was reported by Lin et al. [46]. They obtained a free-standing graphene–sulfur just by ball-milling the graphite and sulfur. Vapor deposition is a high-efficient way to obtain cathodes that fill with smaller sulfur molecules (S2 and S4). Heated above 550 °C, the S8 molecules would break down to smaller S2 and S4 molecules. When the sulfur vapor infiltrates oxygen-rich carbon, an in-situ reduction and recrystallization will start in the matrix. Composite cathodes prepared by that method not only present strong carbon-sulfur bonding but also facilitate the sulfur speciation into porous voids while the matrix could only be oxygen-rich carbon [45]. Liquid phase precipitation could construct the cathodes with sulfur crystallizing in the porous matrixes from nonpolar solvent. Methods that can accelerate the crystallization include adding polar solvent, adjusting pH value and evaporation [47,48]. With merits of low cost, energy efficient and controllability, liquid phase precipitation is a very promising method for fabricating sulfur cathodes [45]. Among various matrixes, carbonaceous materials with hollow structures and porous structures are often used for loading sulfur [49,50], e.g. carbon nanotubes (1D) [51,52], graphene (2D) [53,54] and their composites [55]. The sulfur/carbon composites obtained via the above-mentioned strategies provides a similar structure as the coating methods. Because loading matrixes could be fabricated in advance before introducing sulfur, rather than coating procedure with complicated covering a cladding layer on sulfur particles, loading process is more convenient than coating on constructing composited S/C cathodes. Whereas, considering that building matrixes to hold sulfur is more convenient than covering a cladding layer on sulfur particles, loading process is more widely used than coating on constructing composited S/C cathodes. Since Nazar et al. [56] first used CMK-3, an ordered mesoporous carbon to load sulfur for Li–S batteries in 2009, many researchers have concentrated on utilizing porous substrate to host sulfur. Subsequently developed carbonaceous matrixes, such as micropore carbon [57], mesopore carbon [58], hierarchical porous carbon [49,53,59,60], hollow carbon spheres [61], carbon fibers [62], carbon nanotubes [63–67] and graphene [68–70] all have been reported to be applied in Li–S batteries. These carbon materials share the similar characters of high conductivity, large specific surface area and rich cavities which can help to adsorb polysulfides and confine the active materials within the matrixes. Some of the works exhibited admirable cycle stability with using porous or hollow carbon. One of the typical researches comes from Guo's group [71]. In 2012, they presented a novel electrochemical process with confining chainlike S2−4 in microporous carbon matrix for Li–S batteries. And sulfur that loading on the micropores with diameter of about 0.5 nm could only stay in the metastable state (S2−4). The smaller sulfur molecules avoid the transition between S8 and S4 2− during discharging/charging which contributes to the LiPSs dissolution and exhibit a high Li electroactivity and a novel electrochemical behavior with a single output plateau at ∼1.9 V. The cathode showed a high reversible capacity of 1269 mAh g−1 at 0.1 C, kept capacity retention ratio at nearly 100% from 5th cycle to 200th cycle (remained a reversible capacity of 1149 mAh g−1 at 0.1 C) and exhibited a favorable high-rate capability of 800 mA h g−1 at 5 C. This space-confined chainlike sulfur S2−4 strategy was praised as the most effectively method to avoid shuttle effect and promised a practical Li–S battery with long lifespan. Carbon materials with different structures present various merits. Thus, combining several carbon materials and constructing 3D networks can realize the complementarity from each component. Graphene/porous carbon [72], CNTs/mesopore carbon [73] and graphene/nanofibers [74] are good matrix to host sulfur. Fang et al. [75] designed a hollow carbon fiber foam which consisted of multiwall carbon nanotube and carbon black. The host not only exhibited high absorbability and fixation of polysulfides but also showed exceptional electrochemical performance keeping good cycling stability with sulfur loadings from 6.2 to 21.2 mg cm−2. Apart from utilizing the natural structure of carbon materials, researchers also tried to design ideal matrix manually. Although strategies and composition might vary, the final target for designing diverse sulfur hosts is to achieve high loading and great sulfur retention [12]. Zhang et al. [47] constructed graphitic carbon nanocages (GCNs) with graphene backbone to encapsulate sulfur as shown in Fig. 3(b), which endowed the Li–S battery with a high specific capacity of 1375 mAh g−1, a superior high-rate capability (765 mAh g−1 at 5 C) and a stable long-term cycle life within 1000 cycles. The GCNs can prevent polysulfides from dissolving in the electrolyte, which alleviates the shuttle effect significantly. In addition, the interior graphene backbone and highly-graphitic nanoshells increase electrical conductivity and suppress the volume variation during cycling. 2.3 Separating In 2012, Su and Manthiram [76] introduced a multi-walled carbon nanotube (MWCNT) film between sulfur cathode and separator to adsorb polysulfides and immobilize active sulfur species in cathode side. The strategy provided the battery with significant improvement on cycling performance and less internal resistance. Since then, various synthetic films which were called polysulfide barriers have been used between electrodes and separators [77,78]. The polysulfide barriers for physical separation consist wholly or principally of carbonaceous materials. Porous carbon materials, such as micropore carbon [79], mesopore carbon [77] and hierarchical porous carbon [80], are capable of adsorbing polysulfides for their large specific surface area and abundant pore structure. In addition, carbon nanotubes [76], graphene [81–84] and carbon fibers [85] provide enough space to accommodate polysulfides and they can adsorb the dissolvable polysulfides with resisting the shuttle effect by their large specific surface area and porous network structure. Meanwhile, their unique tubular structure, large aspect ratio and intrinsic conductivity all contribute to improving the electronic and ionic conductivity of the electrochemical process. To fully exert the advantages of various carbon materials, composited polysulfides barriers consisting of various kinds of carbonaceous materials like graphene/porous carbon [86], carbon nanotubes/graphene [87], graphene/carbon nano-fibers [88] can collect different merits and construct 3D network for stabilizing the electrochemical reaction. Peng et al. [89] reported a functioned separator which consists of mesoporous cellular graphene framework (CGF) and polypropylene (PP) to alleviate the shuttle effect and significantly improve the utilization of sulfur. The corresponding mechanism is demonstrated in Fig. 3(c). The surface without a layer of CGF is insulated from the anode, while the other surface qualified with extraordinary electrical conductivity of 100 S cm−1, abundant in-plane mesopores, high electrochemical active surface area of 2120 m2 g−1, and large mesopore volume of 3.1 cm3 g−1, reactivates the shuttling-back LiPSs and preserves the ion channels. The Li–S battery containing the separator exhibited an initial capacity of 1109 mAh g−1 and capacity conserved upon 800 mAh g−1 after 250 cycles at 0.2 C. The result showed 40% higher on sulfur utilization efficiency than the corresponding performance with routine PP separators. As an important technique to confine LiPSs, setting barriers for physical separation of polysulfides is a feasible strategy for improving the cycle performance of Li–S batteries. The carbonaceous materials can ameliorate the interface between electrodes and separators, depressing the interfacial resistance for their high electronic and ionic conductivity [5]. Moreover, special structure design enables barriers to effectively separate, adsorb and accommodate polysulfides, cutting off the shuttle effect and increasing the active materials utilization [90,91]. However, the component that does not take part in the electrochemical reaction will inevitably impair the practical energy density of the battery. In summary, physical confinement of LiPSs including coating, loading and separating mainly works on hampering transports of the shuttle polysulfides. Coating confines active substances within a limited space; loading anchors active substances into matrix; separating prevents LiPSs from transporting through separators. However, they can hardly prevent polysulfides from dissolving into the electrolyte. The cathodes composed by non-polar carbon materials still suffer from capacity decay over long-term cycling. Meanwhile, the strategy inevitably introduces non-electroactive species, which compromise with lowering the energy density of Li–S batteries. 3 Chemical bonding Although carbon materials can act as a physical confinement of polysulfides in Li–S batteries, the nonpolar hosts do no engage in strong interaction with the polar intermediates [92,93]. Capacity attenuation of the battery is inevitable during long cycling as the carbon can just alleviate but not prevent polysulfides from dissolving in the electrolyte [94]. Thus, a variety of host materials with chemical enhancement which exhibit strong interaction with the polysulfides have been fabricated to lick the shuttle effect, such as metal oxides, metal organic frameworks (MOF) and sulfurized polymers. Those materials with absorption function to the polar reactants and products are able to anchor the polysulfides within cathodes, which endows the Li–S batteries a long lifespan and stable capacity retention. In this section, the chemical absorption falls into three categories: polar–polar chemical interaction, Lewis acid-base interaction and sulfurization. Meanwhile, novel host materials with mechanisms of their interaction with the polysulfides are detailed as follow. 3.1 Polar–polar chemical interaction Lithium polysulfides behind shuttle effects are inherently polar molecules and will strongly interact with polar host, which prevents polysulfides from transferring between cathodes and anodes [92]. Thus, substances with strong polarity are all candidates for using in the cathodes. Metal compounds and some silicate are intrinsically polar materials that show strong interaction with polar polysulfides. They can act as adsorbents without further surface modification in the cathodes. However, those compounds [95–98] experiencing poor conductivity can just be used as additives rather than host materials [93]. Thus, they often were combined with carbonaceous materials as composite cathodes, which will be introduced in the next section. Fortunately, researchers discovered that some transition metal compounds with the similar conductivity as metal, such as Ti4O7 [99,100], Ti2C4 [101] and Co9S8 [102] can provide satisfying cathodes. The correlative researches are started by Nazar [103] and Cui [104] in 2014. Ti4O7 which exhibits bulk metallic conductivity as high as 2 × 10 − 3S cm−1 at 298K, is a member of the Ti n O 2n–1 Magnéli phases which are a homologous series of substoichiometric compositions of metallic titanium oxides between the end members TiO2 and Ti2O3 [105]. Nazar used physical and electrochemical probes to demonstrate that polar O–Ti–O units in Ti4O7 have a strong interaction with the polysulfides and put forward that the particle surface promoting the redox process of active materials. And in a lithium–sulfur battery, the Ti4O7 cathode that contains 70 wt% sulfur showed an initial capacity of 850 mAh g−1 at 2 C, with a fade rate of only 0.06% per cycle over 500 cycles. In Cui's research, Density Functional Theory calculations and experimental results also prove that sulfur with its products is apt to gather and deposit on the Ti sites. Moreover, the results can generalize to other kinds of Magnéli phase metal oxides (V n O 2n–1 , W n O 2n–1 , Mo n O 2n–1 , etc.) and some other matrix materials with intrinsic polar character. 3.2 Lewis acid–base interaction Polysulfides with lone electron pairs belong to Lewis base materials. According to Lewis' theory of acids and bases, the anion will interact strongly with materials rich of metal ion sites receiving electrons which renders them Lewis acids [106]. Thus, Lewis acids like MOF and MXene have been reported as hosts to construct cathode composites with sulfur. MOFs are a series of porous materials that consist of metal ions or clusters with a symmetric organic molecule [107]. With high surface area (up to 10,000 m2 g−1) structural diversity and strong interaction sits, they perform well on accommodating the active materials and intermediates in Li–S battery system [108]. MOF was first employed in the cathode of the Li–S battery by Demir-Cakan et al. [109] in 2011. The mesoporous material called MIL-100 (Cr) achieved a marked increase in the capacity retention of the battery. The battery delivers improved performance from the nano-confinement effect of pore structure and metal sites that adsorbed the soluble LiPSs. Subsequently, other porous MOFs including ZIF-8 [106,110,111], HKUST-1 [112,113] and MIL-53 [114] were also utilized as host materials in Li–S batteries. According to pioneering studies, functional groups on the surface of MOFs play a crucial part in the exertion of performance of Li–S batteries. In Tarascon's work, XPS and TEM analysis proved that reversible capture and release of LiPSs were attributed to the O–S surface interaction between the oxygenated framework and the sulfur species [109]. Nonetheless, Zhou et al. [110] discovered that soft Lewis-basic groups, such as amino might increase the energy barrier for charge transfer and hinder the ion diffusion in the MOF channels by comparing MIL-53 (Al) and NH2-MIL-53 (Al) based cathodes in Li–S batteries. The result suggested that some of the MOFs might impose an adverse influence on the Li–S battery. Recently, Siegel and Park [115] used first-principles calculations to investigate the adsorption energies of polysulfides (S8, Li2S4 and Li2S) with 16 metal-substitution variants of M2(dobde) (M = Be, Mg, Ca, Sr, Sc, Ti, V, Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Zn, Mo, Sn). The results revealed that the coordinately unsaturated metal sites provided dominant adsorption that anchored polysulfides on the surface of hosts. Adsorptions of Li2S4, and Li2S were observed stronger than that of S8. In addition, Ti, Ni, Mo were identified as the metal sites with the largest affinities for the polysulfide intermediates (Fig. 4 a), promising their application to confine polysulfides for sulfur cathode in Li–S batteries. However, MOFs are highly electronically insulating hosts suffering the same limit as metal oxides. Batteries with MOF cathodes usually show some letdowns, for examples, low sulfur utilization, poor conductivity and unsatisfying rate performance. Those drawbacks limit their further application in Li–S batteries. Another kind of metal compound, MXene phases own rich interaction sites free from the inherent disadvantage of relatively poor conductivity for MOFs. MXene phases are a series of layered hexagonal materials comprised of transition metals, main-group sp elements, and carbon or nitrogen [116]. Since the first MXene was reported by Naguib et al. [117] in 2011, more than 70 kinds of the phases have been fabricated. The 2D materials qualified with the similar properties as metals, such as high electrical and thermal conductivity, high melting point and as large specific surface area as graphene. The fascinating properties of MXene phases have made themselves the novel alternative in various fields including catalysts, sensors, adsorptions and energy storage. Soon after MXenes being discovered, those materials are considered to promising transition metal carbide anodes for lithium-ion batteries for their high Li storage capacity [118]. Nazar's group [101] for the first time reported that Ti2C MXene phase could exert strong interaction with LiPSs and be used as the matrix for sulfur cathode. The Lewis acid sites Ti and hydroxyl groups on the surface of material were proved to adsorb and interact with LiPSs upon cycling as shown in Fig. 4(b). And the cathode consisted of 70 wt% S exhibited a good cycling performance with a discharge capacity of 723 mAh g−1 after 650 cycles and a capacity fade rate of 0.05% per cycle. With the XPS analyses, the S–Ti–C bonding was proved to be responsible for strong interaction and chemisorption of LiPSs. Since the MXene material was discovered, many researches have concentrated on exploring the mechanism that MXene improves the performance of Li–S batteries at the atomic scale. Nazar's further research [119] demonstrated the detailed mechanism that sulfur attracted to the MXene. Ti–OH bonds on the surface would break as the polysulfides approached. And the strong interaction was subject to formation of thiosulfate. Rao et al. [120] reported the calculation that bare MXenes performed well in trapping all lithium polysulfides. According to their results, –OH has strong attraction to long-chain sulfides while –O prefers the short. The bonding energy of LiPSs with various functionalized Ti2C is showed in Fig. 4(c). Meanwhile, the strong interactions between MXene and LiPSs from Ti–S bonding relieved the shuttle of polysulfides, which improved the performance of the Li–S battery. Apart from MOFs and MXene, another Lewis acid-based material, Prussian blue analogues (PBAs) were also applied as the cathode matrix in Li–S batteries. As Na2Fe[Fe(CN)6] has a large open framework, this material can serve as the storage of sulfur and suppress polysulfides diffusion based on the Lewis acid–base bonding effect. Wang's group [121] wrapped S@Na2Fe[Fe(CN)6] with PEDOT to suppress the shuttling effect and obtain a composite cathode with excellent reversibility, good stability, and fast kinetics. 3.3 Sulfurization Functional polymers that can react with sulfur are also of interest as an alternative cathode hosts to improve cycling stability of Li–S batteries. Heated at above 200 °C, some polymers will be sulfurized and anchor the sulfur with strong chemical bonding [93] During the discharge process, Li2S is generated directly rather than forming lithium polysulfides with continuous breakdown of C–S bonds and meanwhile forms carbon conjugated bonds. The final discharge product is a mixture of the conjugated polymer backbone and Li2S. In the following charging, the conjugated polymer backbone traps Li2S with delocalized radical cations and leads to the growth of cyclic sulfur which has a similar structure as the original [122]. With absence of long chain lithium polysulfides during cycling, the composited sulfur cathodes possess a better cycling performance as solving the shuttle effect problem [123]. Polyacrylonitrile (PAN) is a polymer that has been used as the host material in cathodes of Li–S batteries for a long time. In 2002, wang et al. [124] fabricated a PAN–S cathode by mixing and heating PAN and sulfur at the temperature of 280–300 °C. Constructed with the PAN–S cathode, the battery showed the initial discharging capacity of more than 800 mAh g−1. Although it suffered a relatively low capacity retention, the work showed the potential application of PAN in Li–S batteries. Afterwards, many researchers tried to reveal the mechanism of the sulfurization process. Different with the viewpoint of Wang who believed that sulfur was in elemental in the network of PAN, Yu et al. [125] investigated the products of sulfurized PAN and presented that sulfur molecule reacts with PAN to form a heterocyclic polymeric backbone with polysulfide bonds side-chain. The existence of S–S, C–S and C=C bonds was proved by FTIR spectroscopy [126]. The structure not only anchored the active materials but also avoided forming the dissolve intermediates. During the discharge process, electrons transport through the conjugated main chain. Meanwhile, cyclic S–S and C–S bonds break with formation of conjugated polymers and Li2S [127,128]. Apart from PAN, conductive polymer polyaniline (PANi) was also reported to be used in Li–S batteries. Although the conductive polymer is characterized by good mechanical stability and electronic conductivity in its p-doped state, it will be highly insulating in the reduced state during the cycling in a Li–S battery [92]. Hence different strategies have been used to ameliorate this issue of the conjugated polymer. Xiao et al. [129] reported that they fabricated self-assembled polyaniline nanotubes (SPANi–NT) by heating PANi and sulfur at 280 °C. Sulfur will react with the polymer and form SPANi–NT/S composite with a three-dimensional, cross-linked, nanotubes structure through in situ vulcanization. Some of the sulfur constructs the whole backbones which finally accommodate the rest of those sulfurs. The process of constructing composited cathode SPANi–NT/S is demonstrated in Fig. 4(d). The battery with the SPANi–NT/S cathode could retain a discharge capacity of 837 mAh g−1 after 100 cycles at a 0.1 C. And the Coulombic efficiency of the cathode still remained over 90% after 500 cycles at a discharge rate of 1 C. 4 Composited methods As mention above, physical or chemical process of confining LiPSs often shows limited improvement of Li–S batteries alone. Cathodes consisting of sulfur and carbon materials with special structures are not able to form stable interaction with the active materials and the electrochemical intermediates. Meanwhile, carbon is not able to form a firm interface for attachment of the polar discharging product Li2S. Materials with just physical adsorption are hard to confine polysulfides completely and provide limited improvement of the performance [93]. In comparison, although chemical bonding materials are efficient at providing stable and permanent adsorption, they suffer from low specific surface area and low capacity from sulfur loading. Thus, carbonaceous materials with porous structure are usually reported to be chemical modified and materials with chemical interaction are also integrated with conductive additives or designed into special structures to host sulfur species. In addition, the application of composited materials containing non-polar matrixes and chemical adsorbents exerting the polysulfide adsorbability maximally, shows much enhanced electrochemical properties benefitting from reducing the usage of polar adsorbents, promoting their dispersion and keeping them from aggregation [130]. 4.1 Chemical modification of adsorptive hosts Doping carbon with elements like nitrogen, sulfur, phosphorus or boron is a common method to enhance the chemisorption towards lithium polysulfides without compromising the conductivity [22]. Apart from physical confinement from porous or hollow structures, chemical adsorption renders the matrixes strong interaction with the polar intermediates, which alleviates the shuttle effect and reduces the loss of active materials. Carbonaceous matrixes with designing structures, which are doped by heteroatoms including N-doped hollow carbon spheres [8,131], N-doped porous carbon [132,133], N-doped carbon nanofibers [134], N, B-codoped graphene [135] and N, P-codoped 3D carbon framework [136,137] for Li2S have been used in Li–S batteries and all performed well in catching LiPSs with chemical adsorption. Zhou et al. [29] fabricated a three-dimensional N, S-codoped graphene sponge electrodes and constructed a stable and high-energy-density Li/polysulfide battery. The N, S-codoped graphene sponge electrode provided enough space to accommodate sulfur, rapid transport channels for facilitating transfer of polysulfide ions and strong bound interface with polysulfides. The battery exhibited excellent performance of a high rate capacity of 430 mAh g−1 at 2 C rate after 500 cycles with about 0.078% capacity decay per cycle. Su et al. [138] fabricated a N-doped graphene and carbon nanotube hybrids which was called Fe3C@N–GE–CNTs from Prussian blue (Fig. 5 a). When used as the sulfur scaffold for lithium–sulfur batteries, it demonstrates outstanding electrochemical performance, including a high reversible capacity (1221 mAh g−1 at 0.2 C rate), excellent rate capability (458 and 220 mAh g−1 at 5 and 10 C rates, respectively), and excellent cycling stability (321 and 164 mAh g−1 at 5 and 10 C (1 C = 1673 mA g−1) after 1000 cycles). Apart from doping heteroatoms in carbonaceous materials to create polar sites, functionalizing the host is another strategy to improve interaction. The carbon materials that are decorated with epoxy, hydroxyl and sulfhydryl groups can enhance the binding of S to the C–C bonds due to the chemical interaction from the functional groups [48,123,139]. Huang et al. [140] constructed a nanocomposite that entrapped sulfur into the functionalized hierarchical porous graphene for Li–S batteries (Fig. 5b). The graphene rich of functionalized groups, such as –O–, –OH, had strong attraction for sulfur and polysulfides that showed polar. Combined with large surface area and uniform pore, the graphene accommodates a large amount of polysulfides for Li–S battery. And the as-obtained nanocomposite sulfur electrode exhibits extremely high rate capability which achieved the discharging capacitance of 543 mAh g−1 at a current density of 10 C, respectively. Recently, the electrocatalysis via some inorganic substances has been discovered to enhance the polysulfides conversion reaction kinetics [141]. Al Salem et al. [142] utilized graphene to disperse Pt nanoparticles and obtained the sulfur cathode which not only showed better adsorbability than pristine graphene but also improved the reversibility of deposited short-chain to long-chain polysulfides during the charging process. The electrocatalysis is believed to increase the sulfur utilization, reduce the polarization and suppress the shuttle effect. However, the application of the electrocatalysis strategy is usually limited by its high cost of novel metal electrocatalyst. To tackle this challenge, Zhang's group [143] found that another electrocatalyst, CoS2, played the similar role in the electrochemical reaction process. Due to the strong adsorption to the polar polysulfides and effective catalysis, CoS2 in carbon/sulfur composite cathodes provides a more efficient route for the conversion of S and Li2S (Fig. 5c). The enhanced polysulfides conversion processes significantly mitigated the polarization, promoted energy efficiency and improved the cycle stability. 4.2 Structural design of bonding material Nano-sized metal compounds with active polar site are often added into cathodes as adsorptive additives to adsorb polysulfides rather than act as the host alone in the electrodes, mainly due to their poor conductivity and low specific surface area [22,93,144]. Thus, those metal compounds are usually combined with carbonaceous materials. Some cathodes including MXene/CNTs composited electrodes [78], hollow carbon nanofibers filled with MnO2 electrodes [145] and 3D graphene coated with Al2O3 [146] can significantly improve the cycling stability of Li–S batteries. Lei et al. [147] reported a multi-functional layered WS2 nanosheet with a carbon cloth skeleton (WS2@CNFs) as shown in Fig. 6 (a). The C@WS2 cathode exhibits a high rate capability (≈ 1501 and 450 mA h g−1 are achieved at charge/discharge rates of 0.1 C and 3 C (1 C = 1675 mAh g−1), respectively) with outstanding Coulombic efficiencies (nearly 100%). The battery delivers unprecedented capacity retention in that after more than 1500 cycles at 2 C, and the decay is as low as about 0.0072% per cycle. Apart from just adding into conductive networks, designing appropriate structures for nano-sized metal oxides is another way to fabricate feasible cathodes. As mention above, materials with porous or hollow structures are able to provide physical confinement of LiPSs and accommodate the volume expansion. Thus, nano-sized metal compounds with structural designing can enhance the adsorption to LiPSs [148,149]. As one of most controllable and safe nanomaterials, TiO2 has attracted researchers’ strong interest for its application in Li–S battery [150]. In 2013, Wei Seh et al. [151] for the first time designed a sulfur–TiO2 yolk-shell nanoarchitecture which provided internal void space for the volume expansion of sulfur, with an intact shield to minimize polysulfide dissolution (Fig. 6b). The unique structure of cathodes enables the battery with a high stability that Coulombic efficiency achieved 98.4% over 1000 cycles. Most importantly, the capacity decay after 1000 cycles is as small as 0.033% per cycle. Afterwards, the strategy extended to other compounds such as V2O5 [152], MnO2 [153] and SiO2 [154]. Recently Liang et al. [152] designed a highly efficient polysulfide mediator monoclinic potassium birnessite δ-MnO2 for Li–S batteries. A one-step facile method using GO as the template was applied to fabricate δ-MnO2 nanosheets. The as-obtained S/MnO2 nanocomposite cathode which contained 75% sulfur displayed an initial capacity of about 1300 mAh g−1 at 0.05 C, 1120 mAh g−1 at 0.2 C, and 950 mAh g−1 at 1.0 C. The composite cathode also exhibited an excellent cycling performance with a decay rate of only 0.058% per cycle over 1000 cycles. Some sulfurized polymers were also tried to be design into special structure to improve their physical adsorption of sulfur species. During the sulfurization, the active materials are in intimate contact with the carbon scaffold, which can significantly improve the battery performance [155]. Enlightened by the process of the synthesis of CMK-3, Liu et al. [156] fabricated a sulfurized polyacrylonitrile with mesopore structure (MSPAN), as shown in Fig. 6(c), by in situ polymerizing acrylonitrile in pores of SBA-15, reacting with sulfur and etching out the template with HF subsequently. With highly ordered mesoporous structure and high specific surface area, the as-obtained Li–S battery exhibited excellent Coulombic efficiency, electrochemical performance, and cycling stability. Encapsulation of sulfur into inner nanotube structure is a typical strategy to fabricate available cathodes [157]. Cui's group [158] presented an array of nanofiber to host sulfur. Hu et al. [159] also fabricated a polysulfides cathode consisted of carbon nanotubes (CNTs). The hybrid cathode which was called S-DIB@CNT hybrid composed of CNTs partially filled with a sulfur copolymer was fabricated by an anodic aluminum oxide (AAO) template (Fig. 6d). This structure presented both the physical confinement of LiPSs by CNTs and the chemical bonding of sulfur by binding in the sulfur copolymer. Meanwhile, CNTs in the composite acted as both the electron and ion pathway and host of sulfur; benzene rings in the backbone of sulfur copolymer would interact with lithium polysulfides and prevent them from dissolution. 5 Conclusions and prospects In summary, we have comprehensively summarized recent researches on confining polysulfides within cathodes with physical, chemical and the composited methods in the Li–S battery. Among physical confinement method, there is no doubt that surface coating is an efficient approach to confine polysulfides as well as mitigate volume variation during charging/discharging. It should be emphasized that increase in sulfur particles size accounts for decrease of the factual contact area and might exert adverse effect on the solid phase reaction. Meanwhile, defective coating layers on the surface of sulfur cannot prevent polysulfides from dissolving out completely, which results in inevitable capacity fading of the Li–S battery. Further researches on developing novel strategies of coating are needed to address those issues. Introduction of sulfur into porous materials can also contribute to restricting the shuttle of polysulfides. Loading sulfur into conductive matrix performs well on increasing conductivity of electrode with providing a 3D conductive media while decreases the amount of active materials, leading to low practical capacity of the battery. Similarly, the participation of carbonaceous barrier can suppress shuttle effect with adsorbing and accommodating polysulfides, while the extra component increases the deadweight of the battery at the same time. All the methods need more efficient materials or structure design to increase the loading amount of sulfur or reduce the deadweight of inactive matrixes. For chemical confinement, various materials with chemical interactive sites can provide an intimate affinity with sulfur species through polar–polar chemical interaction, Lewis acid–base interaction and sulfurization and significantly improve the capacity, rate capability and lifetime of the Li–S battery. Nano-sized metal oxides can exhibit strong interaction with polysulfides owing to their polar characteristics. Polysulfides with lone electron pairs are a kind of Lewis base which will form great interaction with Lewis acid materials like MOFs, MXene phases and Prussian blue. Besides, sulfurization not only provides a stable immobilization for the active materials but also eliminate the generation of the dissolvable long chain lithium polysulfides. However, materials of chemical methods to confine polysulfides all suffer from low conductivity and poor stability. Thus, novel chemical systems with interaction with polysulfides are still to be developed. In addition, insulating active materials, drastic volume variation upon cycling and uncontrollable dendrites growth of Li anodes are also restriction that against the application of Li–S batteries [10,160–162]. Thus, we believe that composited methods combined with physical and chemical confinement might be the promising strategy for addressing shuttle effect of polysulfides perfectly. An ideal cathode is considered to be characterized with high content of sulfur, good conductivity, large specific surface area and rich adsorption sites. To realize high sulfur loading, matrixes with hierarchical pores and 3D free-standing structure have been proved to be preferred in the cathodes [70,163]. However, those materials possessing large specific surface area need more electrolyte when they work as cathode matrixes in Li–S batteries. High electrolyte-to-sulfur ratio not only causes practical capacity loss to the battery, but also promotes the dissolution of LiPSs and the shuttle effect. Surface polarity of matrixes takes a crucial part in interacting with sulfur and polysulfides. With strong interactions and proper design of structures, the ideal situation is that host materials with the minimized percentage can encapsulate polysulfides effectively, especially in high sulfur loading cathodes. Still, the cathode with high sulfur loading and adapting to less electrolyte is expect to be developed. More researches are appealed for concentrating on the detailed mechanisms of confining polysulfides on various matrixes which may lead to better understand the shuttle process and open more possible avenue to overcome the bottleneck of Li–S batteries. Novel systems of synergistic effects of physical and chemical methods to confine polysulfides are also needed to promote Li–S batteries to become practical technology in the near future. coredata.dc:description: With high theoretical energy density and the natural abundance of S, lithium-sulfur (Li–S) batteries are considered to be the promising next generation high-energy rechargeable energy storage devices. However, issues including electronical insulation of S, the lithium polysulfides (LiPSs) dissolution and the short cycle lifespan have prevented Li–S batteries from being practical applied. Feasible settlements of confining LiPSs to reduce the loss of active substances and improve the cycle stability include wrapping sulfur with compact layers, designing matrix with porous or hollow structures, adding adsorbents owning strong interaction with sulfur and inserting polysulfide barriers between cathodes and separators. This review categorizes them into physical and chemical confinements according to the influencing mechanism. With further discussion of their merits and flaws, synergy of the physical and chemical confinement is believed to be the feasible avenue that can guide Li–S batteries to the practical application.
